title: Data Extraction
text: trashpanda package includes set data import utilities designed : List files complex directory trees filtering. Safely read multiple file types (CSV, Excel) handling errors. Extract tables arbitrary locations within Excel sheets. tools useful projects data may scattered across folders formatted inconsistently.

title: Data Extraction
text: list_data_files() recursively lists files directory, options filter : File extension (ext) Folder file patterns include exclude Returning tibble list paths Output: tibble file, folder, filename columns, providing clean inventory data sources.
code: library(trashpanda) library(tibble)  # List all Excel files in nested directories containing "results" files <- list_data_files(   path = "path/to/project",   ext = c("xls", "xlsx", "xlsm"),   include = c("results") )  files

title: Data Extraction
text: safe_read_data() reads single file capturing errors. Returns list: data: tibble imported file (NULL failure) error: error message reading failed file: file path especially useful reading multiple files, may malformed.
code: results <- safe_read_data(   file = "data/example.xlsx",   reader = readxl::read_excel,   sheet = "Sheet1",   cols = c("id", "value", "date") )  # Access imported data safely results$data

title: Data Extraction
text: read_data_tree() combines previous functions: Recursively lists relevant files Reads file safely safe_read_data() Optionally enforces consistent column names Combines multiple Excel sheets automatically useful: can process hundreds files scattered different files single call Ensures column names types remain consistent Automatically handles errors skips unreadable files
code: all_data <- read_data_tree(   path = "path/to/project",   reader = readxl::read_excel,   ext = c("xlsx", "xls"),   sheet_pattern = "2026",     # optional regex   cols = c("id", "value", "date") )  all_data

title: Data Extraction
text: Excel sheets messy, tables starting first row. extract_table(): Searches table starting known header (start_column) Optionally identifies multiple tables per sheet (table_mode = "") Adds metadata columns: file name, sheet, table ID function particularly useful : don’t know exact row table starts tables different locations sheet file table somewhat consistent (e.g., know table starts ) Multiple tables exist sheet want keep file sheet metadata
code: tbl <- extract_table(   path = "data/example.xlsx",   sheet = "Sheet1",   start_column = "Sample ID" )  tbl

title: Data Extraction
text: functions can combined batch processing Excel data: example, following occurs: files base (::()) sub directories (recursive = TRUE) extension “.xlsx” listed Tables excel files automatically located read via extract_table function passed reader multiple tables matching criteria sheet, read (table_mode = "") example output looks like following:
code: # Extract tables from all files, safely read_data_tree(   path = here(),   ext = "xlsx",   recursive = TRUE,   reader = extract_table,   start_column = "Sample ID",   table_mode = "all",   safely = TRUE,   id_cols = FALSE ) # A tibble: 40 × 6    sheet_name        `Sample ID` Value Notes Extra  source_file                                                          <chr>             <chr>       <chr> <chr> <chr>  <chr>                                                              1 clean_simple      A1          10    ok    NA     C:/Projects/trashpanda/test/extract_table_test_sheets - Copy.xlsx  2 clean_simple      A2          12    ok    NA     C:/Projects/trashpanda/test/extract_table_test_sheets - Copy.xlsx  3 clean_simple      A3          15    ok    NA     C:/Projects/trashpanda/test/extract_table_test_sheets - Copy.xlsx  4 offset_table      B1          5     low   NA     C:/Projects/trashpanda/test/extract_table_test_sheets - Copy.xlsx  5 offset_table      B2          8     mid   NA     C:/Projects/trashpanda/test/extract_table_test_sheets - Copy.xlsx  6 dynamic_width     C1          1     x     NA     C:/Projects/trashpanda/test/extract_table_test_sheets - Copy.xlsx  7 dynamic_width     C2          2     y     NA     C:/Projects/trashpanda/test/extract_table_test_sheets - Copy.xlsx  8 explicit_last_col D1          100   a     ignore C:/Projects/trashpanda/test/extract_table_test_sheets - Copy.xlsx  9 explicit_last_col D2          200   b     ignore C:/Projects/trashpanda/test/extract_table_test_sheets - Copy.xlsx 10 internal_blanks   E1          1     NA    NA     C:/Projects/trashpanda/test/extract_table_test_sheets - Copy.xlsx # ℹ 30 more rows

title: Plot Extras
text: vignette documents “plot extras” functionality package, including: Adding social media captions plots tables Readable numeric formatting commas Colour palettes scales ggplot2 functions enhance visualization without altering core plotting logic.

title: Plot Extras
text: add_caption_cwb() allows add social media caption ggplot2 plots. supports GitHub Bluesky usernames optionally includes data source.

title: Plot Extras
code: library(ggplot2) library(trashpanda)  p <- ggplot(mpg, aes(displ, hwy)) +   geom_point() +   labs(title = "Displacement vs Highway MPG")  p + add_caption_cwb(type = "plot", github_username = "colebaril", include_data_source = TRUE, data_source = "mpg dataset")

title: Plot Extras
text: add_commas() formats large numbers commas easier readability. particularly useful labeling axes tables numeric readability important.

title: Plot Extras
text: package includes curated palettes different visual moods. Examples include arcane_flame, enchanted_forest, mystic_ocean, .

title: Plot Extras
code: ggplot(mpg, aes(class, fill = class)) +   geom_bar() +   scale_cwb(palette = "discrete_21", type = "d", aesthetics = "fill")

title: Plot Extras
code: ggplot(mpg, aes(displ, hwy, colour = hwy)) +   geom_point(size = 3) +   scale_cwb(palette = "mystic_ocean", type = "c", aesthetics = "colour")

title: Plot Extras
text: arcane_flame enchanted_forest mystic_ocean eldritch_night golden_parchment discrete_21, discrete_31, discrete_35 spotify_pal halloween haunted_forest ghostly_glow blood_moon

title: Plot Extras
text: vignette highlights utility functions enhance plots tables: add_caption_cwb() social media data source captions add_commas() readable numeric labels scale_cwb() applying curated palettes extras integrate seamlessly ggplot2 gt objects streamline polished figure creation.

title: Plot Themes
text: theme_cole() custom ggplot2 theme designed provide restrained, manuscript-like aesthetic. goal heavy ornamentation, clean default : Emphasizes titles axes Reduces unnecessary visual noise Provides fine-grained control axis lines Supports dark mode transparent backgrounds

title: Plot Themes
text: theme built top theme_minimal() modifies focused set elements: Typography: bold titles, slightly larger legend text Layout: increased margins centered titles Axes: explicit control axes shown Backgrounds: light, dark, transparent intent theme works across many plot types without requiring per-plot tweaking.

title: Plot Themes
text: default: Grid lines retained Axis lines appear bottom left Light background used
code: library(ggplot2) library(palmerpenguins) library(trashpanda)  p <- ggplot(penguins, aes(flipper_length_mm, bill_length_mm)) +   geom_point()  p + theme_cole()

title: Plot Themes
text: central feature theme_cole() explicit axis control via show_axis_lines. Valid values : "bottom", "top", "left", "right" "" "none"

title: Plot Themes
code: p + theme_cole(show_axis_lines = c("bottom", "left"))

title: Plot Themes
text: top right axes requested, secondary axes automatically created using dup_axis().
code: p + theme_cole(show_axis_lines = "all")

title: Plot Themes
text: removes axis lines, ticks, text, panel borders entirely.
code: p + theme_cole(show_axis_lines = "none")

title: Plot Themes
text: Grid lines can fully removed using remove_grid = TRUE.  useful presentation-style figures plots intended resemble hand-drawn charts.
code: p + theme_cole(remove_grid = TRUE)

title: Plot Themes
text: Setting dark = TRUE switches theme dark background preserving contrast readability.  Dark mode changes: Plot panel backgrounds Grid line colors Text, axis, legend colors Axis line color automatically adjusted white.
code: p + theme_cole(dark = TRUE)

title: Plot Themes
text: slides, overlays, compositing figures, transparent background can requested:  affects: Plot background Panel background Legend strip backgrounds Note transparency applies light mode.
code: p + theme_cole(transparent = TRUE)

title: Plot Themes
text: theme exposes standard sizing parameters: base_size: base font size (default 12) base_family: font family (default "sans") Titles scaled relative base_size: Plot title: 1.5 × base_size Legend title: 1.2 × base_size keeps proportions consistent across outputs.

title: Plot Themes
text: configuration emphasizes data points labels minimizing distractions.
code: ggplot(penguins, aes(flipper_length_mm, bill_length_mm, fill = species)) +   geom_point(shape = 21, size = 3) +   labs(     title = "Flipper Length vs Bill Length",     subtitle = "Palmer Penguins dataset"   ) +   theme_cole(remove_grid = TRUE)

title: Plot Themes
code: ggplot(penguins, aes(flipper_length_mm, bill_length_mm, color = species)) +   geom_point(size = 2) +   labs(title = "Penguin Morphometrics") +   theme_cole(dark = TRUE, remove_grid = TRUE)

title: Plot Themes
text: theme works best : want consistent, restrained styling across figures Axis placement matters (e.g., publication teaching figures) need light, dark, transparent variants without redefining themes intentionally opinionated avoids heavy stylistic elements can layered captions, annotations, custom geoms.

title: Plot Themes
text: theme_cole() provides: clean extension theme_minimal() Explicit axis-line control Dark transparent modes Sensible typography defaults implementation prioritizes clarity, reuse, predictable behavior across plotting contexts.

title: Utilities
text: vignette covers general utility functions included package: cite_packages() – generates formatted citations loaded packages load_quarto_theme() – loads precompiled Quarto CSS theme project utilities help manage reproducibility presentation styling.

title: Utilities
text: cite_packages() prints package citations either R Markdown/Quarto style plain text console. default, cites currently loaded packages.

title: Utilities
text: Wickham H, Henry L (2026). purrr: Functional Programming Tools. doi:10.32614/CRAN.package.purrr https://doi.org/10.32614/CRAN.package.purrr, R package version 1.2.1, https://CRAN.R-project.org/package=purrr. Wickham H, François R, Henry L, Müller K, Vaughan D (2023). dplyr: Grammar Data Manipulation. doi:10.32614/CRAN.package.dplyr https://doi.org/10.32614/CRAN.package.dplyr, R package version 1.1.4, https://CRAN.R-project.org/package=dplyr. Wickham H (2016). ggplot2: Elegant Graphics Data Analysis. Springer-Verlag New York. ISBN 978-3-319-24277-4, https://ggplot2.tidyverse.org. Baril C (2026). trashpanda: Cole’s personal collection R functions, themes, palettes. R package version 0.0.1, commit 14145a48ec656cb89aa5ca8a60aeb12a5c89b085, https://github.com/colebaril/trashpanda. Rinker TW, Kurkiewicz D (2018). pacman: Package Management R. version 0.5.0, http://github.com/trinker/pacman. Output formatted direct copy-paste R Markdown Quarto documents.
code: library(pacman) # load some packages p_load(trashpanda, ggplot2, dplyr, purrr)  cite_packages(format = "rmd")

title: Utilities
text: prints citations plain text, suitable scripts reports. Note: Packages without registered citation generate warning.
code: cite_packages(format = "text") ## [[1]] ## Wickham H, Henry L (2026). _purrr: Functional Programming Tools_. ## doi:10.32614/CRAN.package.purrr ## <https://doi.org/10.32614/CRAN.package.purrr>, R package version 1.2.1, ## <https://CRAN.R-project.org/package=purrr>. ##  ## [[2]] ## Wickham H, François R, Henry L, Müller K, Vaughan D (2023). _dplyr: A ## Grammar of Data Manipulation_. doi:10.32614/CRAN.package.dplyr ## <https://doi.org/10.32614/CRAN.package.dplyr>, R package version 1.1.4, ## <https://CRAN.R-project.org/package=dplyr>. ##  ## [[3]] ## Wickham H (2016). _ggplot2: Elegant Graphics for Data Analysis_. ## Springer-Verlag New York. ISBN 978-3-319-24277-4, ## <https://ggplot2.tidyverse.org>. ##  ## [[4]] ## Baril C (2026). _trashpanda: Cole's personal collection of R functions, ## themes, and palettes_. R package version 0.0.1, commit ## 14145a48ec656cb89aa5ca8a60aeb12a5c89b085, ## <https://github.com/colebaril/trashpanda>. ##  ## [[5]] ## Rinker TW, Kurkiewicz D (2018). _pacman: Package Management for R_. ## version 0.5.0, <http://github.com/trinker/pacman>.

what: 2. Loading a Quarto theme with load_quarto_theme()
title: Utilities
text: load_quarto_theme() copies precompiled CSS file package project can use Quarto presentations revealjs.

previous_headings: 2. Loading a Quarto theme with load_quarto_theme()
title: Utilities
code: css_path <- load_quarto_theme(name = "dark") ## CSS theme 'dark' is already in 'styles'. You can use it in your Quarto YAML: ##   css: C:/Projects/trashpanda/vignettes/styles/trashpanda-dark.css # Use in Quarto YAML: # css: styles/trashpanda-dark.css

previous_headings: 2. Loading a Quarto theme with load_quarto_theme()
what: Example: load the light theme into a custom folder
title: Utilities
text: ensures consistent styling slides without manually copying files.
code: css_path <- load_quarto_theme(name = "light", dest_folder = "styles/custom", overwrite = TRUE) ## CSS theme 'light' has been copied to 'styles/custom'. You can now use it in your Quarto YAML: ##   css: C:/Projects/trashpanda/vignettes/styles/custom/trashpanda-light.css

title: Utilities
text: utilities vignette demonstrates: create reproducible citations cite_packages() integrate precompiled Trashpanda Quarto themes projects load_quarto_theme() tools complement visualization workflow functions package, supporting reproducible research presentation-ready outputs.

title: Authors and Citation
text: Cole Baril. Author, maintainer.           2026

title: Authors and Citation
text: Baril C (2026). trashpanda: Cole's Personal Collection R Functions, Themes, Palettes. R package version 0.0.1, https://colebaril.github.io/trashpanda/.
code: @Manual{,   title = {trashpanda: Cole's Personal Collection of R Functions, Themes, and Palettes},   author = {Cole Baril},   year = {2026},   note = {R package version 0.0.1},   url = {https://colebaril.github.io/trashpanda/}, }

title: Cole's favourite functions and themes
text: ’ve ever seen digging nested folders dumpster-diving one CSV file, know ’s just typical day life data wrangler; usually, just feel like trash panda. Half columns missing, files won’t even open, everything else misnamed: chaos, pure simple. ’s exactly built trashpanda: help tame messy file systems, clean unruly data, beautify plots, manage colour palettes, automate little tasks normally make want throw computer real dumpster fire.

title: Cole's favourite functions and themes
text: can install development version trashpanda GitHub :
code: devtools::install_github("colebaril/trashpanda")

title: Cole's favourite functions and themes
text: following example, theme_cole() used alter thematic elements plot scale_cwb() used apply custom colour palettes. also use add_caption_cwb() function automatically insert caption pre-formatted icons social media tags. can easily flip dark mode!
code: require(pacman) p_load(trashpanda, ggplot2, palmerpenguins)  ggplot(penguins, aes(flipper_length_mm, bill_length_mm, fill = species, group = species)) +   geom_point(shape = 21) +   geom_smooth(aes(colour = species), se = FALSE, method = "lm") +   scale_cwb(name = "Species", palette = "arcane_flame", type = "d", aesthetics = "fill") +   scale_cwb(name = "Species", palette = "arcane_flame", type = "d", aesthetics = "colour") +   theme_cole(show_axis_lines = c("bottom", "left"), remove_grid = TRUE) +   labs(title = "Palmer Penguin Bill Length \nvs. Flipper Length", x = "Flipper Length (mm)", y = "Bill Length (mm)") +   add_caption_cwb(type = "plot") ggplot(penguins, aes(flipper_length_mm, bill_length_mm, fill = species, group = species)) +   geom_point(shape = 21) +   geom_smooth(aes(colour = species), se = FALSE, method = "lm") +   scale_cwb(name = "Species", palette = "arcane_flame", type = "d", aesthetics = "fill") +   scale_cwb(name = "Species", palette = "arcane_flame", type = "d", aesthetics = "colour") +   theme_cole(show_axis_lines = c("bottom", "left"), remove_grid = TRUE, dark = TRUE) +   labs(title = "Palmer Penguin Bill Length \nvs. Flipper Length", x = "Flipper Length (mm)", y = "Bill Length (mm)") +   add_caption_cwb(type = "plot")

title: Cole's favourite functions and themes
text: example, clean_data() used standardize column names, trim white space, convert empty columns true NAs, flags outliers numeric columns using robust means.
code: df <- tibble::tibble(   "First Name" = c(" Alice ", "Bob", "", "CHARLIE", "dave", "Eve", NA, "Bob", "Bob"),   "Last Name" = c("Smith", "Jones", "O'Neil", "Brown", "Miller", "O'Brien", "", "Jones", "Jones"),   "Score" = c(10, 5000, 15, 20, 12, -999, 14, 5000, 5000),     "Enrollment Date" = c("2025-01-01", "20241215", "2025/02/01", "", NA, "01-03-2025", "2025-01-01", "2024-12-15", "2024-12-15"),   "Grade" = c("A", "b", "C", "A", "B", "", "A", "b", "b"),   "Comments!" = c("Good", " Excellent ", "", "Needs work", NA, "Good!", "Average", " Excellent ", " Excellent "),   "EmptyCol" = c(NA, NA, NA, NA, NA, NA, NA, NA, NA) )  print(df) #> # A tibble: 9 × 7 #>   `First Name` `Last Name` Score `Enrollment Date` Grade `Comments!`   EmptyCol #>   <chr>        <chr>       <dbl> <chr>             <chr> <chr>         <lgl>    #> 1 " Alice "    "Smith"        10 "2025-01-01"      "A"   "Good"        NA       #> 2 "Bob"        "Jones"      5000 "20241215"        "b"   " Excellent " NA       #> 3 ""           "O'Neil"       15 "2025/02/01"      "C"   ""            NA       #> 4 "CHARLIE"    "Brown"        20 ""                "A"   "Needs work"  NA       #> 5 "dave"       "Miller"       12  <NA>             "B"    <NA>         NA       #> 6 "Eve"        "O'Brien"    -999 "01-03-2025"      ""    "Good!"       NA       #> 7  <NA>        ""             14 "2025-01-01"      "A"   "Average"     NA       #> 8 "Bob"        "Jones"      5000 "2024-12-15"      "b"   " Excellent " NA       #> 9 "Bob"        "Jones"      5000 "2024-12-15"      "b"   " Excellent " NA  clean_data(df, trim_chars = TRUE, empty_to_na = TRUE, flag_outliers = TRUE) #> # A tibble: 8 × 8 #>   first_name last_name score enrollment_date grade comments   empty_col #>   <chr>      <chr>     <dbl> <chr>           <chr> <chr>      <lgl>     #> 1 Alice      Smith        10 2025-01-01      A     Good       NA        #> 2 Bob        Jones      5000 20241215        b     Excellent  NA        #> 3 <NA>       O'Neil       15 2025/02/01      C     <NA>       NA        #> 4 CHARLIE    Brown        20 <NA>            A     Needs work NA        #> 5 dave       Miller       12 <NA>            B     <NA>       NA        #> 6 Eve        O'Brien    -999 01-03-2025      <NA>  Good!      NA        #> 7 <NA>       <NA>         14 2025-01-01      A     Average    NA        #> 8 Bob        Jones      5000 2024-12-15      b     Excellent  NA        #> # ℹ 1 more variable: score_outlier_flag <lgl>

title: Cole's favourite functions and themes
text: ’m wrangling messy data across multiple folders files, read_data_tree() go-helper. recursively searches folder files, reads safely (even files malformed), combines everything single tidy tibble. Excel sheets mixed types? problem — columns safely coerced won’t get errors binding rows. can also select specific sheets name pattern, filter extensions, enforce consistent columns.
code: # Read all CSV files in nested "Test" folder, ignore "extra folder" results_csv <- read_data_tree(   path = "C:/File_Path",   ext = "csv",   exclude = "extra folder",   reader = readr::read_csv,   cols = c("id", "value", "date") )  # Read all sheets in all Excel files containing "Data" in the sheet name results_excel <- read_data_tree(   path = "C:/File_Path",   ext = "xlsx",   reader = readxl::read_excel,   sheet_pattern = "Data",   cols = c("a", "b", "c") )

title: Cole's favourite functions and themes
text: Find tables within multiple Excel files sheets regardless table within sheet extract_table() function. example , every excel file base directory read. Within Excel file, tables start Sample ID located data tables combined one tibble. automatically detects sample ends can specify ending column. can also specify number empty rows allowed table deemed ended. See extract_table() documentation details.
code: read_data_tree(   path = here(),   ext = "xlsx",   recursive = TRUE,   reader = extract_table,   start_column = "Sample ID",   table_mode = "all",   safely = TRUE,   id_cols = FALSE )

title: Cole's favourite functions and themes
text: Using trashpanda::cite_packages() function, can easily cite packages used script file, choosing R Markdown output plain text options. Horst , Hill AP, Gorman KB (2020). palmerpenguins: Palmer Archipelago (Antarctica) penguin data. doi:10.5281/zenodo.3960218 https://doi.org/10.5281/zenodo.3960218, R package version 0.1.0, https://allisonhorst.github.io/palmerpenguins/. Wickham H (2016). ggplot2: Elegant Graphics Data Analysis. Springer-Verlag New York. ISBN 978-3-319-24277-4, https://ggplot2.tidyverse.org. Baril C (2026). trashpanda: Cole’s personal collection R functions, themes, palettes. R package version 0.0.1, commit 14145a48ec656cb89aa5ca8a60aeb12a5c89b085, https://github.com/colebaril/trashpanda. Rinker TW, Kurkiewicz D (2018). pacman: Package Management R. version 0.5.0, http://github.com/trinker/pacman.
code: cite_packages(format = "rmd")

title: Adds commas to large numbers for easier readability. — add_commas

title: Adds commas to large numbers for easier readability. — add_commas
code: add_commas(x)

text: x numeric vector.

title: Adds commas to large numbers for easier readability. — add_commas
text: character vector length x commas inserted thousand separators.

title: cast_safe_df() — cast_safe_df
text: Safely run function return consistent data frame Executes function handling errors empty outputs gracefully. Returns tibble original results, plus context error columns.

title: cast_safe_df() — cast_safe_df
code: cast_safe_df(   fun,   ...,   context = NULL,   placeholder = tibble::tibble(result = NA) )

title: cast_safe_df() — cast_safe_df
text: fun function execute. ... Arguments passed fun. context Optional character string describing context call (e.g., filename input value). Defaults NULL. placeholder tibble return function fails returns empty data frame. Defaults tibble(result = NA).

title: cast_safe_df() — cast_safe_df
text: tibble containing: result output function (placeholder failed). context context string provided. error error message function failed, otherwise NA.

title: cast_safe_df() — cast_safe_df
text: function useful safely executing functions may fail inputs, reading multiple files may missing malformed. ensures output always tibble can safely combined using purrr::map_df().

title: cast_safe_df() — cast_safe_df
code: library(tibble) library(purrr) library(readr)  # Example 1: math function with possible errors f <- function(x) {   if (x == 0) stop("Cannot divide by zero!")   10 / x } nums <- -1:1 out <- map_df(nums, ~ cast_safe_df(   f, .x,   context = paste("value =", .x),   placeholder = tibble(result = NA_real_) )) #> Warning: Error in value = 0: Cannot divide by zero! print(out) #> # A tibble: 3 × 3 #>   result context    error                  #>    <dbl> <chr>      <chr>                  #> 1    -10 value = -1 NA                     #> 2     NA value = 0  Cannot divide by zero! #> 3     10 value = 1  NA                      # Example 2: reading multiple files safely df <- map_df(list.files(pattern = ".csv", full.names = TRUE),              ~ cast_safe_df(readr::read_csv, .x,                            col_names = FALSE,                            show_col_types = FALSE,                            context = basename(.x),                            placeholder = tibble(X1 = NA_character_)))

what: Cites packages in various formats (e.g., R Markdown/Quarto or plain text). — cite_packages
title: Cites packages in various formats (e.g., R Markdown/Quarto or plain text). — cite_packages
text: Cites packages various formats (e.g., R Markdown/Quarto plain text).

title: Cites packages in various formats (e.g., R Markdown/Quarto or plain text). — cite_packages
code: cite_packages(format = "rmd", packages = pacman::p_loaded())

title: Cites packages in various formats (e.g., R Markdown/Quarto or plain text). — cite_packages
text: format Character, either "rmd" Markdown/Quarto "text" console output. packages Character vector package names. Defaults pacman::p_loaded().

title: Cites packages in various formats (e.g., R Markdown/Quarto or plain text). — cite_packages
text: Invisibly returns NULL. Side effect: prints formatted citations.

title: clean_data — clean_data
text: function tidy data

title: clean_data — clean_data
code: clean_data(   df,   clean_names = TRUE,   trim_chars = TRUE,   empty_to_na = TRUE,   standardize_case = c("none", "lower", "upper", "title"),   remove_special_chars = FALSE,   collapse_rare_levels = FALSE,   coerce_date = FALSE,   flag_outliers = FALSE,   drop_empty_rows = TRUE,   distinct = TRUE,   drop_missing_threshold = NULL,   verbose = FALSE,   return_summary = FALSE )

title: clean_data — clean_data
text: df data frame clean. clean_names Logical. TRUE, standardizes column names using janitor::clean_names(). Default TRUE. trim_chars Logical. TRUE, trims whitespace character columns. Default TRUE. empty_to_na Logical. TRUE, converts empty strings "" NA character columns. Default TRUE. standardize_case Character. One "none", "lower", "upper", "title". Adjusts character/factor casing. Default "none". remove_special_chars Logical. TRUE, removes punctuation/special characters character columns. Default FALSE. collapse_rare_levels Logical. TRUE, lumps rare factor levels "". Default FALSE. coerce_date Logical. TRUE, converts date-like character columns Date. Default FALSE. flag_outliers Logical. TRUE, flags numeric outliers. Default FALSE. drop_empty_rows Logical. TRUE, removes rows columns NA. Default TRUE. distinct Logical. TRUE, removes exact duplicate rows. Default TRUE. drop_missing_threshold Numeric 0–1. Remove columns fraction missing values. Default NULL (disabled). verbose Logical. TRUE, prints summary cleaning actions. Default FALSE. return_summary Logical. TRUE, returns list cleaned df summary actions. Default FALSE.

title: clean_data — clean_data
text: cleaned data frame / tibble, list df summary return_summary = TRUE.

title: clean_data — clean_data
code: df <- tibble::tibble(   "First Name" = c(" Alice ", "Bob", "", "CHARLIE", "dave", "Eve", NA, "Bob",    "Bob"),   "Last Name" = c("Smith", "Jones", "O'Neil", "Brown", "Miller", "O'Brien",    "", "Jones", "Jones"),   "Score" = c(10, 5000, 15, 20, 12, -999, 14, 5000, 5000),  # includes outlier   "Enrollment Date" = c("2025-01-01", "20241215", "2025/02/01", "", NA,    "01-03-2025", "2025-01-01", "2024-12-15", "2024-12-15"),   "Grade" = c("A", "b", "C", "A", "B", "", "A", "b", "b"),   "Comments!" = c("Good", " Excellent ", "", "Needs work", NA, "Good!",    "Average", " Excellent ", " Excellent "),   "EmptyCol" = c(NA, NA, NA, NA, NA, NA, NA, NA, NA) ) clean_data(df, trim_chars = TRUE, empty_to_na = TRUE) #> # A tibble: 8 × 7 #>   first_name last_name score enrollment_date grade comments   empty_col #>   <chr>      <chr>     <dbl> <chr>           <chr> <chr>      <lgl>     #> 1 Alice      Smith        10 2025-01-01      A     Good       NA        #> 2 Bob        Jones      5000 20241215        b     Excellent  NA        #> 3 NA         O'Neil       15 2025/02/01      C     NA         NA        #> 4 CHARLIE    Brown        20 NA              A     Needs work NA        #> 5 dave       Miller       12 NA              B     NA         NA        #> 6 Eve        O'Brien    -999 01-03-2025      NA    Good!      NA        #> 7 NA         NA           14 2025-01-01      A     Average    NA        #> 8 Bob        Jones      5000 2024-12-15      b     Excellent  NA

what: Look for and extract a table anywhere within an Excel sheet. — extract_table
title: Look for and extract a table anywhere within an Excel sheet. — extract_table
text: Searches Excel sheet table whose header contains known start column. table may appear anywhere sheet.

title: Look for and extract a table anywhere within an Excel sheet. — extract_table
code: extract_table(   path,   sheet = 1,   start_column,   last_column = NULL,   search_until_empty_header = TRUE,   max_empty_rows = 2,   na_values = c("", NA),   table_mode = c("first", "all"),   safely = TRUE,   id_cols = TRUE,   quiet = FALSE,   ... )

title: Look for and extract a table anywhere within an Excel sheet. — extract_table
text: path Path Excel file sheet Sheet name index start_column Name first expected column last_column Optional name last expected column search_until_empty_header Logical; auto-detect column end max_empty_rows Number consecutive empty rows tolerated na_values Values treated NA safely Logical; TRUE, return empty tibble failure id_cols Logical; add file/sheet metadata columns quiet Logical; suppress messages ... Arguments passed directly reader

title: Look for and extract a table anywhere within an Excel sheet. — extract_table
text: tibble

what: List data files in nested folders — list_data_files
title: List data files in nested folders — list_data_files
text: Recursively list files directory, optionally filtering file extension, folder filename patterns, inclusion/exclusion rules.

title: List data files in nested folders — list_data_files
code: list_data_files(   path,   ext = NULL,   include = NULL,   exclude = NULL,   recursive = TRUE,   return_list = FALSE )

title: List data files in nested folders — list_data_files
text: path Character. base directory start searching . ext Character vector NULL. File extensions include (e.g., c("xls", "xlsx", "xlsm")). Case-insensitive. Default NULL (extensions). include Character vector NULL. Patterns must present file path. Multiple patterns -ed, .e., patterns must match. Can include regex expressions. Default NULL (include filtering). exclude Character vector NULL. Patterns must present file path. Multiple patterns -ed, .e., files matching exclude pattern removed. Can include regex expressions. Default NULL (exclusion filtering). recursive Logical. search include subfolders? Default TRUE. return_list Logical. Whether list returned instead tibble. Default FALSE.

title: List data files in nested folders — list_data_files
text: tibble column file containing full file paths.

title: List data files in nested folders — list_data_files
code: # List all xlsx and xlsm files in any "results" folder for 2024-2026 if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ list_data_files(   path = "C:/my_base_dir",   ext = c("xls","xlsx","xlsm"),   include = c("results", "2024|2025|2026") ) } # }

what: Load a Trashpanda Quarto theme into the current project — load_quarto_theme
title: Load a Trashpanda Quarto theme into the current project — load_quarto_theme
text: Copies precompiled CSS theme project 'styles/' folder use Quarto presentations revealjs.

title: Load a Trashpanda Quarto theme into the current project — load_quarto_theme
code: load_quarto_theme(   name = c("dark", "light"),   dest_folder = "styles",   overwrite = FALSE )

title: Load a Trashpanda Quarto theme into the current project — load_quarto_theme
text: name Theme name ("dark", "light") dest_folder Destination folder project (default: "styles") overwrite Whether overwrite CSS already exists (default: FALSE)

title: Load a Trashpanda Quarto theme into the current project — load_quarto_theme
text: Relative path CSS file project

what: Read all data files from a folder tree safely — read_data_tree
title: Read all data files from a folder tree safely — read_data_tree
text: Recursively reads multiple data files (CSV, Excel, etc.) directory tree. Automatically handles errors, enforces column names, combines multiple sheets Excel files. Always returns tibble consistent columns.

title: Read all data files from a folder tree safely — read_data_tree
code: read_data_tree(   path,   reader,   cols = NULL,   ext = NULL,   include = NULL,   exclude = NULL,   recursive = TRUE,   sheet = NULL,   sheet_pattern = NULL,   anti_sheet_pattern = NULL,   ... )

title: Read all data files from a folder tree safely — read_data_tree
text: path Character. Base directory search data files. reader Function. Reader function file type (e.g., readr::read_csv, readxl::read_excel). cols Character vector NULL. Columns enforce; missing columns added NA. ext Character vector NULL. File extensions include (e.g., c("csv", "xlsx")). Case-insensitive. include Character vector NULL. Patterns must present file path. exclude Character vector NULL. Patterns must present file path. recursive Logical. Whether include subfolders. Default TRUE. sheet Character vector NULL. Specific sheet names read (Excel ). NULL, explicitly specified sheet read files. sheet_pattern Character NULL. Regex pattern match sheets (Excel ). NULL, sheets matching pattern attempted read. anti_sheet_pattern Character NULL. Regex pattern exclude sheets (Excel ) ... Additional arguments passed directly reader().

title: Read all data files from a folder tree safely — read_data_tree
text: tibble combining successfully read files (columns enforced source_file added).

what: Safely read a data file with consistent output — safe_read_data
title: Safely read a data file with consistent output — safe_read_data
text: Reads data file using user-supplied reader function, returning tibble along error message encountered import. useful batch-reading many files may malformed inconsistent.

title: Safely read a data file with consistent output — safe_read_data
code: safe_read_data(   file,   reader,   cols = NULL,   sheet = NULL,   sheet_pattern = NULL,   anti_sheet_pattern = NULL,   ... )

title: Safely read a data file with consistent output — safe_read_data
text: file Character string. Path file read. reader Function used read file (e.g., readr::read_csv, readxl::read_excel). function must take file first argument. cols Optional character vector column names enforce output. Missing columns added filled NA, extra columns dropped. sheet sheet selected static name. NULL, explicitly specified sheet read files. sheet_pattern Optional regex pattern select sheet name. NULL, sheets matching pattern attempted read. anti_sheet_pattern Character NULL. Regex pattern exclude sheets (Excel ) ... Additional arguments passed directly reader().

title: Safely read a data file with consistent output — safe_read_data
text: named list following elements: data tibble containing imported data, NULL error occurred. error NULL file read successfully; otherwise, character string containing error message. file input file path.

title: Safely read a data file with consistent output — safe_read_data
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ files <- c("data/a.csv", "data/b.csv")  results <- lapply(   files,   safe_read_data,   reader = readr::read_csv,   cols = c("id", "value", "date") )  # Extract successfully read data good_data <- purrr::keep(results, ~ is.null(.x$error)) } # }

title: Cole's colour scales — scale_cwb
text: Apply palette ggplot colour fill scale.

title: Cole's colour scales — scale_cwb
code: scale_cwb(   palette,   type = c("d", "c"),   aesthetics = c("colour", "fill"),   name = NULL,   ... )

title: Cole's colour scales — scale_cwb
text: palette Name palette (e.g., "arcane_flame"). type Scale type: "d" discrete "c" continuous. aesthetics Aesthetic apply ("colour" "fill"). name Legend title. ... Additional arguments passed ggplot2 scale functions.

title: Cole's colour scales — scale_cwb
text: ggplot2 scale object.

title: Cole's colour scales — scale_cwb
code: library(ggplot2) library(trashpanda) ggplot(mpg, aes(class, fill = class)) +   geom_bar() +   scale_cwb(palette = "eldritch_night", type = "d", aesthetics = "fill")   ggplot(mpg, aes(displ, hwy, colour = hwy)) +   geom_point(size = 3) +   scale_cwb(palette = "mystic_ocean", type = "c", aesthetics = "colour")

title: Cole's favourite plot theme — theme_cole
text: ggplot2 theme styled resemble old parchment ink, giving plots vintage, manuscript-like appearance.

title: Cole's favourite plot theme — theme_cole
code: theme_cole(   base_size = 12,   base_family = "sans",   remove_grid = FALSE,   show_axis_lines = c("bottom", "left"),   dark = FALSE,   transparent = FALSE )

title: Cole's favourite plot theme — theme_cole
text: base_size Base text size. Default 12. base_family Base font family. Default "sans". remove_grid Logical. TRUE, removes grid lines. show_axis_lines Shows axis lines, text, titles ticks. Choose "", "none", "bottom", "top", "right", "left"; default: c("bottom", "left"). dark Logical. TRUE, plot transformed dark theme. transparent Logical. TRUE, plot background transparent.

title: Cole's favourite plot theme — theme_cole
text: ggplot2 theme object can added ggplot plots.

title: Cole's favourite plot theme — theme_cole
text: theme adjusts panel backgrounds, grid lines, text colors evoke look old parchment handwritten ink. Works ggplot2 plots.

title: Cole's favourite plot theme — theme_cole
code: library(ggplot2) library(trashpanda) library(palmerpenguins)  ggplot(penguins, aes(flipper_length_mm, bill_length_mm, fill = species, group = species)) +   geom_point(shape = 21) +   labs(title = "Flipper Length vs. Bill Length",        subtitle = "Lorem ipsum") +   theme_cole(show_axis_lines = c("bottom", "left"), remove_grid = TRUE, dark = TRUE) +   add_caption_cwb()  #> Warning: Removed 2 rows containing missing values or values outside the scale range #> (`geom_point()`).        ggplot(penguins, aes(flipper_length_mm, bill_length_mm, fill = species, group = species)) +   geom_point(shape = 21) +   labs(title = "Flipper Length vs. Bill Length",        subtitle = "Lorem ipsum") +   theme_cole(show_axis_lines = c("bottom", "left"), remove_grid = FALSE) +   add_caption_cwb()  #> Warning: Removed 2 rows containing missing values or values outside the scale range #> (`geom_point()`).
